columns: An experiment to cut logs in preparation for processing elsewhere. Replaced by Filebeat: https://github.com/elastic/beats/tree/master/filebeat
data:
Updated the links to Filebeat

We merged the Beats in a single repo, so we have a new location for Filebeat.
This updates the links from the README file.

Fixes #402

Tell the human who installs the package where to find logs

I would do this in the `/etc/init.d/logstash-forwarder start` output,
but I'm pretty sure systems like puppet/chef/etc rely on specific
confines of the output of init scripts, so there's probably nothing we
can output there. I'd love to know if this isn't true.

Change working directory and log path

* Now logs to /var/log/logstash-forwarder/...
* Now runs in /var/lib/logstash-forwarder/...

Fixes #402

Tell update-rc.d to actually do the work

This should solve this error that occurs during deb removal:

    update-rc.d: /etc/init.d/logstash-forwarder exists during rc.d purge (use -f to force)

Set TLS min version to TLS 1.0

Fixes #402

This allows tests to run under JRuby

Fixes #402

disable deb specs for now until I make them work

Fixes #402

Hack to make `go build` work when using a weird directory structure.

`go build` by default compiles the main package into a binary named
the same as the current directory. Sometimes folks do things to
cause this directory to not be named "logstash-forwarder"
(for example, as reported in #388).

This change makes all `go build` documentation/invocations force the
output binary name to be "logstash-forwarder" regardless of the
parent directory name.

Fixes #402

More progress in a package deployment test

Still trying to figure out how to reliably generate an ssl certificate
that has an IP SAN.

Might give up and use /etc/hosts instead.

Fixes #402

WIP to get the deb package tested

Runs an Ubuntu 14.04 docker image and installs the package and runs
lsf pointed at our local lumberjack server.

This test is currently breaking because we aren't generating an
ssl certificate with an IP SAN.

Copy example from the README but commented most things out.

These are copied from logstash replacing name with logstash-forwarder.

These are used to create the logstash-forwarder user and do other
maintenance tasks during package installation/removal.

Some OS distributors ship an incomplete ruby as the "ruby" package
that can only be completed by installing "ruby-dev" or "ruby-devel"
(the name changes depending on which platform you're on)

This is in response to a comment on #284:
> First off, "gem install fpm" failed mysteriously, until I realized I
> also need to install the ruby-dev package

Fix an issue when creating frames with accented characters, I have
changed the frame creation to use bytesize instead of length.  I have
also moved the encoding method outside of the client class, it make
things easier to test and support.

Unrelated, but it felt good to do:
This purges all the old 3rd party vendor fetching stuff that was
used in the older C implementation of logstash-forwarder, and
this also removes some experimental Go stuff I had been working on.

Initial effort to rewrite the integration specs to make them pass.

These haven't really passed for over a year and the project is hurting
for it.

This change makes the Lumberjack::Server a bit easier to test by
allowing easier access to accept a single connection. The monolithic
`run`  method wasn't a great idea anyway.

The current spec suite will write 3 lines to a file and will verify that
logstash-forwarder will read a file and forward its data to a lumberjack
server.

Merge pull request #264 from avleen/patch-1

Prevent closing the wrong connection

Prevent closing the wrong connection

In the event of an SSL error (eg, bad certificate from a client), `client` here still pointed to the last successful connection.
So when a client failed to connect, and `client` still pointed to the last successful connection, we were forcing that good connection to be closed.

This PR sets `client` to `nil`, before accepting a new connection, and then tests to make sure it's not `nil`, before closing it.

Merge pull request #188 from pilif/support-more-ssl-cert-hashes

support for newer SSL certificate types

support for newer SSL certificate types

more and more CAs are using certificates signed using SHA256 or SHA512,
whereas go's X.509 support by default only supports certificates signed
with a SHA1 hash.

Importing the two hashes causes them to be registered and available to
use for x509 which in turn allows connecting to servers using one of
these newer certificates

- version bump to 0.0.20
- remove zeromq because it's not used yet.

Merge pull request #156 from elasticsearch/gofmt

gofmt -tabs=false -tabwidth=2

gofmt -tabs=false -tabwidth=2

I am not very happy with the formatting gofmt provides, but as there's
the cult of gophers who seems to love this tool, it makes sense to try
to avoid "why not gofmt!?" discussions and not distract existing go
users with differing code style.

Next step is obviously to write logstash-forwarder in !Go just to
avoid formatting wars, right? ;)

os.Rename fails on windows if the file exists. I can find no way to
invoke ReplaceFile via Go, so lumberjack's registrar updates will not
be atomic on Windows platform. On windows, the "old" registrar db is
saved as ".lumberjack.old"

This has one slight behavioral change from the C version. We now
send a window size change before every spooled payload. This has
the effect of allowing slow publishers to be acknowledged sooner.

for now)

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:jordansissel/lumberjack

Conflicts:
	Makefile

- use nonblockign reads/writes to signal timeouts instead of
polling/select; seems more reliable? I've had selects timeout when I'm
certain there's data to read.
- sample code for new lumberjack receiver

- set LINGER period to 0 so that when we call Close() (usually on

Forget EventEnvelope, just ship a slice.

Merge pull request #37 from igalic/gmake

Don't make assumptions about make

Don't make assumptions about make

use MAKE variable, set it to a sensible default.

- Give up after 24 hours on idle files (todo: make this configurable)
- fix off-by-one on offset counts
- support stdin if the path  is simply "-"
Call it 'Spool'. More iteration on the behavior as well; now emits an evelope

- make prospector check for inode/dev file rotations
  this will let harvesters continue to read 'old files' until they stop
  being written to, which will solve some race conditions and especially
  solve 'bad rotations' where logrotate renames, but the application
  writing to the log file isn't notified and keeps writing to the old
  one.
more work in progress on harvester management

- use 'next_flush_time' as a time.Time instead of computing
  duration-since-last-flush-or-start; I think it makes the code more
  readable to say "is the current time after next_flush_time?"

- start a prototype of lumberjack in go + zmq + protobufs
  Same functional goals, different implementation and wire protocol.

- fix RUSAGE_RSS mis-setting due to bad math
- remove newlines from log calls

- make report interval relative to the window size
- remove some newlines in logs

Revert "- upgrade to zeromq 3"

This reverts commit e348e1131a65dc15307b193185b1bd06fe441b19.
- try to get the errno if ssl error is syscall related

- set read/write timeouts to 30 seconds
- more logging

refactor 'is this socket usable?' into lumberjack_poll.
This is now used to determine if a socket is readable/writable before
attempting to do so; a timeout will cause a disconnect and retry.

- truncate the io_buffer *before* we write out the window size,
  otherwise the client never receives it. Duh!

- only log wait_for_ack events on failure
- log sequenced acked for debugging
- only flush if necessary when idle
- port is unsigned. (fixes crash if you attempted to use a port >32768)
bump gemspec version for the ECONNRESET catching

- Set ack timeout to 10 seconds instead of 30. The aim is to help
  reduce bursted recoveries (massive pushes on a successful reconnect
  after an ack timeout)
- Attempt to deal with slow/stalled reads

- only log which host we've selected if there are multiple hosts in the
  list (aka, lumberjack --host server1,server2,server3

- Always truncate the output io_buffer on connect. This fixes a serious
  bug where sometimes the retransmit-on-reconnect would dump part of the
  old buffer on the wire.

- Comment and log improvements
- Typo fix where commas were used instead of semicolons
- style fixes
indicate how many bytes were read

- @ssl_server.accept does the handshake, and if it fails, we should
  simply drop the connection, not raise an exception.

Merge pull request #22 from sgzijl/patch-1

Build requirements (FPM/Outgoing FTP).

Build requirements.

The build process needs FPM and FTP access to ftp.openssl.org.
- log slow SSL_read and SSL_write calls

- set default window size to 4096. Shown better performance at high
  event rates than previous of 1024.

- duh, the 'nfds' arg isn't number of fds, it's the max filedescriptor
  number + 1. Actually have timeouts work now.

- refactor to do less reads and less string concatenation
  Performance improves 3.5x -
    Previous: 30 seconds for 500,000 messages
    This commit: 8.5 seconds for 500,000 messages

- use zmq_poll to wait for a zmq message for up to 1 second, this has
  the effect that we will only 'idle flush' once per second at most.
- move to using flog instead of printf

- use OpenSSL's pseudo random generator instead of libc's rand()

  The main issue is that srand(time()) is insufficient to prevent
  thundering herd when restarting hundreds of lumberjack nodes
  simultaneously (All restarts in the same second have the same seed, so
  are likely to choose the same lumberjack host to connect to first)
- Add note that I currently have no intention to rewrite lumberjack in Go.

- add how to use with logstash
- slight tweaks to other sections
- start hacking on a logging method
- wrap read calls for now for debugging
- catch OpenSSL errors thrown in MRI

- copy in WIP of lumberjack in golang.
  Main goal is to pick up go as a language again, but I might stick with
  it if deploying a go binary is easier. The code's certainly more
  flexible with less effort.

- Add libapr
- try experimenting with a shorter/simpler install script

- detect backwards sequences
- use the window size itself, not divided by 2 (was cut in half for
  debugging long ago) ;)
- commit work in progress websocket viewer

- add an 'age' filter
- add logstash config

- fix writer
- add ssl key gnerator
- start working on a load tester for lumberjack
